ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Essential for anyone in anthropology and very interesting for those in other departments. It prompts you to think about identity, politics, ideology, and communication in a different way.
Not in the position to answer this. I'd have to talk to individual student about what he or she expects to take away from the course first.

I would definitely recommend this course to any student interested in the intersections of language, culture and ideology. The course material is friendly to students from multiple disciplines, which makes class discussions both engaging and educative.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It fleshed out aspects of anthropology I had never encountered before. I hope to revisit some of these concepts in my dissertation work in the future.

It fulfills my expectations to know more about structuralism. It is just good to have more tools in the conceptual bags of tricks. Whether or not they will work with the issue at hand is a test of a student's thinking ability and it is always a long shot.
